description: From Middle English crupper, crouper, cropere, from Anglo-Norman cruper, cropere, from Old French cropiere, crupiere, from the same Germanic root as croup. Doublet of croupiere.

entries.meaning: A strap, looped under a horse's tail, used to stop a saddle from slipping.
examples: he eſpied a mule's crupper, which hung to the ceiling of the room; this he took down, and tendering it to Don Quixote, went on, ſaying...

entries.meaning: The buttocks or rump, especially of a horse.
A piece of armour covering the hindquarters/buttocks of a horse.

verbs.description: crupper (third-person singular simple present cruppers, present participle cruppering, simple past and past participle cruppered)

entries.meaning: To fit with a crupper; to place a crupper upon.
